SENT.plain: Benign intracranial hypertension-pseudotumor cerebri (PTC) is a rare disease in childhood
We report about our experience in five children with PTC, aged two to ten years
The main symptoms were headache, palsy of VI.th cranial nerve and papilledema
Neuroradiologic studies showed normal ventricles in four and a slit ventricle in one
Enlarged optic nerve sheaths were found in one child prior to therapy
The cerebro spinal (CSF) fluid pressure varied from 380 mm to 480 mm CSF
Four children received acetazolamide, one child dexamethasone
Permanent visual deficit did not occur in any child
